posts.name: Ainesh Yarlagadda
posts.cooked:
This year, for various reasons, for the first time I’ve been in FRC there was a lot of variation in how teams approached auto align in this year’s game. I’ve seen everything from 6328’s mind boggling approach by basically automating all matchplay, to navigating to any branch position, to not auto align at all. And this is only what I’ve seen.

So I was wondering - does your team have a somewhat different approach than what you’ve seen normally to auto align? For example, my team had the driver controller vibrate whenever the driver was okay to place to coral, which was our approach to auto align.

link_counts.title: How do you line up on the reef?

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: I responded then realized I only read the title and not the body of it, whoops. Our team didn’t do anything terribly unique but I did see a cool solution with pink team 233. They had a camera facing the poles and a monitor with two pieces of tape on it. If the reef pole was between those pieces of tape on the monitor, they knew they were aligned.

posts.name: Ryan Shavell
posts.cooked:
Our auto-align handled alignment and scoring once it was activated - our driver held one of two buttons to signify if he wanted to score on the left or right branch of the closest reef face, then one of four buttons to signify L1/L2/L3/L4.

When the position & height buttons were held the robot drove to the correct scoring position with a motion profiled PID , set the arm and elevator to the correct scoring setpoints, and would release the coral once the drivetrain and mechanisms were at their target positions. We’d rumble the controller when this sequence ended to signal to the driver that he could start the next cycle.

We accomplished most of the automation that occurred on  top of the PIDs using Trigger composition, which is all done in our RobotContainer file here if you want an example. Our process was essentially:

DriveToPose command targeting the reef that is triggered by the left & right-align buttons

Commands to set mechanism PIDs that are controlled by Triggers checking for if the reef is being targeted & how close we are to it

A command to score the coral, triggered by if the reef is being targeted & all necessary mechanisms are in position

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked: Here are some previous threads on the question (don’t mean to shut this one down, just helping to keep them cross-referenced).

link_counts.title: Let’s Review REEFSCAPE’s Controls Software Strategy: How did you solve position and accuracy with software?
From zero to auto align to reef tutorial how to simply auto align to the reef
Teams, how do you tune Auto-Align and Vision to competition fields (Particularly for Reef Alignment)?

posts.cooked:
We put everything for alignment in one command that does a PID loop on the error between the Limelight MegaTag2 estimated position and the desired pose. It doesn’t use the SwerveDrivePoseEstimator odometry at all. This works really well by itself but we marginally improved the convergence behavior with this .

The desired pose is calculate with trigonometry from the reef angle. We have two cameras exactly 6.5 inches from the center (distance between reef branch and apriltag) so there’s always a Limelight that sees the tag.

Then there’s some other stuff for automatically raising the elevator and ejecting the coral by checking distance/error to the desired position.

link_counts.title: What cool things did you do in Software this year?

posts.name: Jack Ross
posts.cooked: We decided for a relative approach to the April tags for reef alignment. It was our first year using swerve so it could have been better. We used 3 PIDs to calculate the X,Y,and Yaw of the April tag using PhotonVision. Then we fed that data into a drive command to move it to the April tag. We had trouble in the beginning using it because our camera position was too low and close to the bumper. But overall we had accouple of good days with it.

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: We did a lot of iteration on camera placement this season. Our lesson learned is likely in most(all?) future games, camera position is something needs to be an early driver in design of the robot architecture.
